DataElement.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Clinical Information Group Pathologist Assessment Tumor Grouping Pathologic Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.:Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.:Knowledge derived from study, experience, or instruction that has been gathered or received by communication.:Any number of entities (members) considered as a unit._Pathologist is a doctor specialized in medical diagnosis based on the macroscopic and microscopic study of structural changes of tissues and organs caused by the disease.:The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of._the pathologic stage grouping of a tumor.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.:Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation. Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.
Knowledge derived from study, experience, or instruction that has been gathered or received by communication.
Any number of entities (members) considered as a unit.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pathologist is a doctor specialized in medical diagnosis based on the macroscopic and microscopic study of structural changes of tissues and organs caused by the disease.:The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

Concepts.definition: Any physician whose career is devoted to the study of pathology.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Pathologic; caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
